commit.message:
Fix paged inventory menu if the player has no gear (Bamboolord)

If the player had no gear, but did have other items, the inventory would
nonetheless display as empty and close on any keypress.

Don't make summoned exploders explode on timeout (Flugkiller)

This was pointed out first for stokers (whose creeping infernos would
immediately explode upon the summoner's death). There was discussion about
canonizing this behavior (or making them function more like ball lightning
in general), but I'm still generally dissatisfied enough with stokers that
I'd want to examine their design in more detail instead, which I'm leaving
for hellpan work in 0.35.

Mildly adjust the way petrification works

One of the key things that distinguishes petrification from paralysis is
that the player always gets a chance to respond to it before it happens.
Except... that technically isn't true if the player is unlucky enough:
applying petrifying to an already petrifying target instantly finishes the
petrification. With walking earthen tomes often casting it many times in a
single turn, it was very possible to get instantly petrified with no
recourse.

This commit removes that behavior for both monsters and players (it wasn't
even documented in-game, to my knowledge!).

At the same time, it attempts to give a consistent 30 aut to respond to
beginning to petrify (rather than it depending somewhat unintuitively on
how slow youe previous action was). This meant that while the player could
usually perform 2 normal speed actions before petrifying, sometimes they
could not (which could be very unexpected).

Finally, spellpower of the monster petrify spell is increased somewhat in
compensation, as well as the chance for clouds of calcifying dust to
petrify the player.

Adjust various timing issues with Paralysis (Acrobat), and tweak Vex

The way paralysis timing was handled internally had some wierd and
unintuitive interactions with minipara in particular. While theoretically
intended as a 1-turn paralysis, if it happened to the player while they
were taking a 10 aut (or longer) action, it you wouldn't actually cause
them to lose any time at all! But if the action was faster than that, they
would in fact lose 10 aut. (ie: Moving and getting minipared = 10 aut,
Attacking at 0.7 delay and getting miniparaed = 17 aut). This meant that
in many 1v1 situations, minipara might have literally no effect besides
looking very scary.

This situation is a result of two things:
 a) While stunned by any means, the player passed time in 10 aut
    increments (meaning 1 aut of remaining paralysis will still consume 10
    aut)
 b) Paralysis loses duration at the *start* of the player turn (meaning it
    will immediately lose duration equal to the speed of the previous
    action).

(a) is easy to fix - we now pass time in 10 aut increments while stunned,
unless the remaining stun time is less than 10 aut, in which case we pass
only that much time.

(b) is a bit harder. Ignoring the turn spent becoming paralysed would make
full paralysis while slowed/statue significantly worse that is right now.

However minipara should do *something*, so I am opting for all player
paralysis to last 5 aut more than previously (along with not always
rounding to 10 aut intervals on decay). Considering players spend a lot of
time attacking things at faster speeds than 1.0 (for which this will often
reduce duration slightly), this isn't a strict buff to the effect, but
should hopefully make it slightly more consistent - particularly for
minipara.

In addition, this rewrites some very old logic that technically allowed
paralysis from god wrath to stack in duration with other sources (except
in ways that could sometimes resulted in *reducing* how paralysed you are
instead.) This is too niche to be concerned with, and now they simply won't
attempt to paralyse you if it wouldn't work.

(This will result in a minor bug in upgraded saves where the notes for
paralysis from prior to this commit will display their durations divided by
10. I decided this wasn't worth the save compat code.)

Finally, this makes a modest chage to Vex behavior. Instead of the player
attacking at 1.0 speed no matter what, they will attack with their normal
attack delay (and if there isn't enough aut left at the end of the effect
for another attack, simply pass the remaining time.)

Slightly refactor actor::cannot_act()

The current behavior of ::cannot_act() is moved to ::helpless(), while
::cannot_act() gets daze and vex folded into it, instead of checking for
those manually in multiple places.

The idea is that cannot_act() means "Cannot take independent action"
without any stabbability or EV penalty (which is implied by helpless())

Multiple places have been given the newly correct function call, as
appropriate.

Don't give 0 Chei piety for kills of paralysed/petrified things

This may be the only case of a temporary status effect changing the reward
a monster gives. And Chei is fine with killing things in their sleep,
anyway!

Print a message for curare applying slow even if the victim is paralysed

UI consistency is better than worrying about how physically visible slow
movement is while paralysed. You can see the icon anyway!

Prevent monster lookup sometimes displaying astronomical damage numbers

If we were constructing a monster_info from a monster type (rather than a
specific monster), slaying was left undefined, which could sometimes
result in xv listing arbitrarily large ints worth of melee damage.

Make a Xom action use a common method

This use of this logic was overlooked when I pulled it out from
Gravitambourine and Sign of Ruin into its own method.

Give dispersal traps a short cooldown (and fix a bug)

While dispersal traps have an interesting effect that can rapidly
recontextualize combat, there are many scenarios where - once they are
first triggered - it becomes impossible to prevent monsters from rapidly
retriggering it for many turns in a row, making combat overly chaotic and
uncontrollable. This can be especially true in parts of Tomb, with its
confined spaces and swarms of batty death scarabs.

Now, each time a given dispersal trap activates, it goes dormant for 4-7
turns, during which it will not trigger at all. This should be often enough
to remain very relevant without leading to situations where the positions
of everything get randomized constantly.

At the same time, this commit fixes another bug where monsters were blinked
by dispersal traps in expanding radius order, which could lead to the same
monster being potentially blinked many times (ie: a monster close to the
trap would be blinked slightly further away, then be found again as the
iteration continued, blinked again, etc.) This was functionally fairly
similar to blinking each monster once, but tended to produce more clouds,
more messages, (and probably had a slightly higher chance of blinking
monsters out of LoS entirely). Now it should blink each monster exactly
once.

Tweak Ignis fire champion wrath

While this wrath will be a little more likely to happen now, the actual
effect of it is pretty tame, even by the standards of Ignis wrath. It's
a minor damage and movespeed boost to a single normal monster - typically
less threatening than even a single fire elemental.

The fire champion status now also applies +7 AC and rF+ to the monster
(mirroring some of the player's own benefits from Ignis) and can be applied
to a random 1-3 monsters at a time instead of only 1.

The aim here isn't to make Ignis wrath significantly more dangerous
overall, but slightly more varied.
Describe chaoslace and fire champion effect on attacks more fully in xv

Give Ignis's Fire Champion effect the same treatment

This should also make it a little more common, now that it can apply to
monsters with attack flavors.

Make chaoslace apply AF_CHAOS on top of normal attack flavor (regret-index)

Rather than replace it outright for a monster's first attack only (which
had awkward interactions with some monsters).

Correct a comment

absdepth0 is 0-indexed not 1-indexed (confusingly, since it isn't in lua).

There are 16-year-old comments suggesting this should be changed. Perhaps
it should be, but I'm not doing it this very moment.
Don't trigger explore teleport traps when there are no monsters to tele to

Fix explore traps being delayed by one turn when taking stairs (Acrobat)

Also possibly in some other circumstances.

(update_screen() might look like a rendering method, but this also controls
initial discovery of tiles and thus explore trap triggers)

Fix the lua add_ench() monster method (dilly)

Broken by 6d4169bc. In that commit, any lua calls adjusted to not
specify a degree where broken, since the API function still always
wanted the degree argument. This commit adjusts the API function to use
a degree default of 0, changing that value to the 3rd argument when that
value is supplied and is a number.
Add another graffiti wares quality.
Rename and resort more graffiti tags.
Expand a graffiti master class message.

Rename @coloured_graffiti@ tag to @any_graffiti@.

Since it's no longer in the colour names database.
Rename and resort non-graffiti author tags.
Rename and resort graffiti author tags.

Move graffiti author names to graffiti.

Since they're not all proper names per se.

Split off graffiti into its own database entry.

Keeping it in the colour names database is unwieldy.
Add another master class to graffiti.

Cut down more on substring usage.

Also add death mages as another name for necromancer types, and simplify
one substring.
Tweak a graffiti master class message.
Add a few more master classes to graffiti.
Consolidate/reweight class-related graffiti.
Reweight a few graffiti advertisements.
Advertise the paint used in graffiti.
Add a few shop references to graffiti.
Expand graffiti master class teachers.
Restructure graffiti advertisements.
Add another glowing adjective to colours.
Replace artefact names overlapping w/new egos.
Add bee-related graffiti.

Don't use a deprecated lua math function

The `math.atan()` can be used in place of the now-removed `math.atan2()`
function.

Don't unmarshall numeric lua marker data as float

Our marshalling code has apparently never worked properly for float lua
numeric values. That is, any precision in the value of a marshalled
numeric lua value would be removed, since the value is cast to integer.
In the conversion to lua 5.4, the map marker marshalling code wasn't
updated to push the unmarshalled value as an integer lua value and now
always pushes a floating point one.

Going forward, we should either have a scheme for marshalling lua
numeric types properly or at least error when a caller attempts to
marshall a numerica lua value that's actually floating point. The former
probably involves having every instance of lua marshalling use
file.marshall_meta() and using the same floating point/int union kludge
we use for marshalling/unmarshalling float values elsewhere in save
files. Since there are no cases of attempted marshalling of non-integer
numeric values in the current lua marker code that I can see, maybe just
adding checks/errors is the best approach for now.
Fix a crash with failing to reach past an ally to attack empty space

Increase Shadowslip's piety cost

While I don't want to overly kneecap the 'backstab' Dith archetype *too*
heavily, Shadowslip provided an awful lot of both defensive and offensive
utility for its very low cost, and especially in the hands of stabbers
might be a bit too good. Let's see if this is a better spot for it.

Don't refresh shadow mimic HP on each trigger while Misdirect is active

Since the shadow mimic is recreated every time it triggers, each proc
effectively fully heals it. This is more or less intentional in normal
usage (and it's not very durable anyway), but Shadowslip's misdirection
effect is specifically intended to end when the shadow is killed and also
gives a invo-based max hp boost to make it more durable. Being able to
repeatedly trigger full heals in this state probably contributes a bit too
much to its longevity in stabbing scenarios (and also in an RNG-prone way)

Instead, preserve its current health during misdirection, each time it
respawns (but increase the invo-based max HP bonus very slightly).

Clarify the invis static targeter a little

There's been some confusion from players unfamiliar with the new behavior
for quaffing !invis, and think they are actually being asked to use the
potion on an enemy.

Hopefully by changing some wording and being more a little wordy elsewhere,
there will be less confusion.

Update beholders at the start of the player's turn, too (Acrobat)

We primarily scanned for whether to break mesmerisation/fear at the end of
the player's action. This meant that many things which happened on the
monster's turn to change LoS would not break the effect until the end of
the *following* turn (even if the player clearly could not see the
beholder at all on their turn).

This could even lead to perceived inconsistencies. For example, if reading
?fog created enough clouds to immediately break LoS with a beholder,
mesmerisation would end. But if they did so via spreading later on (in
manage_clouds()), LoS would often still appear to be immediately obscured
to the player, but mesmerisation would *not* end.

Now in addition to checking at the end of the player's turn, we also check
at its start, which should fix these issues.

Replace blizzard demon bolt of cold with Deflect Missiles (regret-index)

Picking up what nekomata lost, this spell is a natural thematic fit for
them, and they had more unique ways of dealing ranged cold damage already,
anyway.

The cast weight of bolt of cold was split among their 3 remaining offensive
spells.

Upgrade monster Repel Missiles to Deflect Missiles

While monster repel missiles did reduce incoming damage, it often didn't
do so by enough that a player felt motivated to deviate from their primary
strategy - even if that strategy was firing missiles. In many realistic
cases, it was worth less than one pip of a resistance (despite being much
rarer than those).

This boosts its effect from +15 EV to +24 EV, making it closer to a 50%
damage reduction against average monsters and further than that for evasive
ones. hellmonk felt it should also be renamed if it was going to be
stronger than the player effect, so now it is.

A few monster changes were made in compensation for this:
 -Sojobo and spriggan air mages lose a little EV
 -Nekomata lose repel missiles entirely, without replacement. (They're
  scary enough as it is!)

(Enchantress is realistically virtually missile-immune at this point, but
her defenses have always been very polarizing and I think it's fine if
alternate strategies are strictly required.)

Fix /mindburst penetrating multiple monsters (Acrobat)

Apparently the mindburst zap was always flagged as penetrating, and merely
prevented from doing so elsewhere until 04a2e7c. Who knew?

(I've double-checked other enchantments and don't see anything else that
was overlooked.)

Change attack verbs for whips

"You punish the ogre, causing immense pain!" was always a very silly line,
but it is also periodically a point of confusion for players, who think
the phrasing implies that some debuff was inflicted (and/or that it has
something to do with negative energy or the Pain brand).

Let's discard the current whip damage verb progression entirely and replace
it with: flog -> flagellate -> thrash mercilessly

Buff Injury Bond, nerf Marytr's Knell in compensation

When used by most monsters, Injury Bond tends not to play especially
interestingly. Since you still inflict just as much total damage (just
split between two people), unless one target is especially high priority,
there isn't any particular impetus to play differently than otherwise.
Preserver bands in particular tend to be fairly homogeneous in threat, so
it doesn't really matter who you're hitting. And when used by orc apostles,
it may be actively negative (by concentrating more damage on one apostle,
who might then die when they otherwise would not have).

So instead of the caster taking the full brunt of the redirected damage,
let's have them take only 50% instead (ie: 100 damage dealt -> 50 to the
original target and 25 to the Injury Bond caster). This will make it more
efficient to actually take out a preserver first in some cases and
hopefully make it play better on apostles.

However, Martyr's Knell already made good use of the effect as it was, and
I don't want to wildly increase its effectiveness, so I am reducing the
shade's health and regen significantly. And then since that would *also*
make it much easier to convert into a flayed ghost off direct damage, am
increasing its defenses. This is hopefully at least roughly in the ballpark
of its present power.

Change duration stacking behavior of a few monster mass buffs

Battlecry, Hunting Call, Injury Bond, and Mass Regeneration would not
reapply their corresponding buff to any ally which already had them. This
sometimes meant that a monster could get caught in a cycle of 'buff wears
off exactly one ally', 'rebuff just that one ally', 'buff wears off the
next ally', 'rebuff just that one ally', and so forth.

Now when they use these effects, it will refresh their duration on all
eligable allies in range, even if they still have some duration remaining
(but will cap their duration at the higher of 'new duration' and 'remaining
duration', rather than stack indefinitely).

Don't give monster alerts for friendly/good-neutral monsters (pisaster)

This fixes #4946

Don't give a message when firewood leaves view

Resting in a place such as the Desolution of Salt that places a lot of
fog clouds would often end up with the rest getting interrupted by a
plant or petrified plant or other firewood monster leaving view.

Fix Dith shadow mimic triggering 100% of the time (kawtan)

Left a testing statement in by accident, whoops!

Fix all allies refusing to fire piercing beams the player isn't immune to

Regardless of whether they were remotely aimed in your direction or not.

(Was broken by 302e8de)

Fix a couple Xom banishment-related issues and simplify

When e2fda63 fixed Xom only ever fake-banishing (regardless of player XL),
it also accidentally mostly prevented fake-banishing from happening at low
XL *and* left a very, very small chance to get banished for real at low XL
too. But the code was very old, and mildly confusing in its application,
so I have simplified.

Fake banishment can happen without any XL check (it's harmless, after all!)
Real banishment now becomes *more* common with XL rather than less (this
behavior long predates the Abyss having depth-scaling, so late banishment
was very harmless, whereas late Xom banishment now should still remain
dangerous.)

Overall rate of banishment should be fairly minimally affected on the
whole.

Remove extra whitespace in the middle of encounter message for Abyss spawns

(At least the ones that have equipment, which is admittedly not many.)

Don't do level catchup after exiting Okawaru's Arena (Odds)

Time technically always passed outside while one was Duelling, but old
level catchup code was unreliable, so this wasn't always obvious. However,
new level catchup code is quite reliable, so Duelling a monster would
often result in returning to the level completely surrounded by whatever
other monsters were nearby.

Now time outside the arena should be 'frozen' for most purposes.

Don't give monster alerts for firewood (Flugkiller)

Even if the player has (for whatever reason) enabled
monster_alert += trivial they probably still don't want a message-less
--more-- for every plant they see.

Properly do kill effects when you kill a dormant tesseract

Instead of leaving the other one still alive (and able to activate, even!)

This fixes #4952 and #4953

Don't daze friendly monsters when a tesseract dies

This was originally unintentional, though I did ponder keeping it for a
while (ie: Zot's power overwhelms *all* monsters, not just those on its
side). In the end, I think it creates more niche awkwardnesses than it
probably adds.
Add another type of graffiti ordinary meeting.
Add another type of graffiti relative.

Move haunting graffiti into vengeance graffiti.

Since the two can overlap.

Expand vengeance graffiti.

It's now open to everyone, although still more common among orcs, and
has more options.
Fix spelling.
Add a bit more Zin and Beogh graffiti.

Fix monster manifold assault extending player berserk

We were counting all casts of manifold assault including those of
monsters as the player attempting an attack. This would extend the
duration of any status effects on the player that last longer when
attacking such as berserk and detonation catalyst.

Give Bestow Arms a chance to produce the new brands

(Note that Bestow Arms doesn't currently generate axes or staves, but it
will have a chance to produce the other ones.)
Allow brand weapon scrolls (and randarts) to produce the new brands

Fix oni potion cleave sometimes being instant and using no potion

If the player drank a potion which was not useful for any purpose besides
triggering an attack, and that attack removed all eligable monsters from
your attack range (often by killing them, though blinking via distortion
would also work), by the time it came to actually drink the potion, the
game would find that it was useless, and neither drink the potion nor
consume any time.

In theory, you could get dark maul cleaves 'for free' this way (by, say,
drinking !magic at full MP), though in practice it was probably hard to
exploit very often.

Remove a redundant method

This was strictly redundant with calling wearing_ego with OBJ_WEAPONS.

Make monsters swapping with each other not consume so much energy

A monster swapping places with another monster cost an astounding *3* turns
worth of energy: one each for the acting monster and the monster it swapped
with, and then an additional one for the acting monster due to what I can
only assume was a bug with the return value, causing the monster to
think it didn't move at all and use a turn's worth of energy to stand in
place.

A monster swapping with another monster *already* pushes that monster's
action back by moving it backwards (and usually causing it to spend another
turn getting back to where it already was). It doesn't need to double
penalize both of them (and in fact, this could cause bands of normal-speed
enemies to rapidly fall behind the player on open ground, as monsters would
repeatedly step in front of the band leader, only to get swapped past,
costing both of them multiple turns like some kind of comedy sketch of
people tripping up in each other's limbs.)

The player swapping with other monsters already didn't deduct energy from
the other monster, so now monsters doing so doesn't either (and the
double-cost bug is also fixed; it existed since at least 0.13!)

Remove a very silly assert and slightly tidy

Heaven forfend if a monster should reach to attack something that hasn't
even been reified yet.

Fix issue with allied monster sidestepping and tweak

The code which handled making monsters sometimes sidestep in melee to allow
ranged monsters behind them to attack the player had 2 bugs since 7ec163d.

The first was considering a monster blocked so long as its threat range
could *reach* them, rather than reach *past* them (which would be required
for them to hit something else.) Notably, this could result in things
repeatedly dancing in circles to try and get out of the way of the melee
attacks of monsters behind them.

The second was inverted logic in the genus check; it was intended that
hostile monsters only sideside for same-genus monsters, while friendly
monsters could sidestep for anything. The inverse was happening.

However, I have also decided that this genus check is opaque and silly;
lots of intelligent monsters clearly on the same faction do not belong to
the same genus. Should a vault warden be so heedless of the yaktaurs in
their very own band? Should a beastmaster ignore their own beasts? The
only demon genuses shared by more than one monster are 'hell lord' and
'pandemonium lord'.

Instead, all intelligent monsters will be willing to sidestep for ranged
allies, with one caveat: they will avoid doing this for their own summoner
(if applicable), since this tends to help the player instead.

In keeping with this, the separate check that causes sidestepping to allow
adjacent allies through when there is no other path around them is *also*
loosened for intelligent monsters, who will try to let anything else past
in chokepoints.

Fix an off-by-1 error in draw_ring_animation()

Outward animations were one radius smaller than they should have been.

Remove an ancient hack

This code was added ~19 years ago as a band-aid over some bug that caused
monster speed values to sometimes become garbage. I have to assume that
this bug has stopped existing in the intervening decades (also, what even
was the original logic for 'If a monster accumulates 12 unspent turns at
once, leave them with exactly 6 of them' anyway? Or '129 speed is a sane
value', for that matter.)

Fix most normal friendly summons being unable to appear in Sanctuaries

(Not *all* friendly monster creation goes through create_monster(), but
most of it does.)

Don't allow spectral weapons to make attacks of opportunity

They're not supposed to attack independently at all.

(Frankly, there are checks in enough different places to prevent them from
doing this that it would be nice to have a less hacky solution that just
didn't give them a melee attack at all outside of the
spectral_weapon_fineff itself somehow.)

New short blades brand: Devious

This brand gives +10% chance to perform low-tier stabs against valid
targets and gives a stacking boost to slaying and EV each time any stab is
performed. This stacks up to 3 times, giving +4 EV and +3 slaying per
stack, and will be maintained so long as the wielder continues to attack
(though is otherwise short-lived).

In the same spirit as Protection brand, when in the hands of monsters,
this brand gives a flat +8 EV and +6 slaying, since monsters cannot stab
things at all.

(Brand icon made by regret-index, using Ontoclasm's potion of berserk rage
icon.)

New maces brand: Concussion

This brand causes all of the wielder's hits to push their victim backwards
and then follow them if they were the primary target of the attack (which
is to say that things like WJC whirlwind and Xom cleave status won't move
you in random directions, but still push things away).

Monsters displaced this way suffer a ministun proportional to your attack
delay (so finessed whips can't stunlock things), while those unable to
move because of a solid feature at their back will be crushed against it
and take +~25% damage instead. This gives the player a solid direct offense
boost based on positioning, as well as the ability to better-maneuver
enemies to take advantage of this. (And in cases where it is safe and
viable to shove an enemy across the floor, you can get a defensive benefit
for doing so.) WJC also opens up interesting possibilities with whirlwind
opening up space and lunges quickly isolating monsters from their allies.

(The player cannot be ministunned from being hit by this, but super-trample
can obviously be very disruptive to their positioning.)

(Brand icon made by regret-index, editing a CC0 weapon icon made by Shade)

New axes brand: Sundering

This brand causes each consecutive melee attack to store up power,
eventually unleashing it in a single massive attack that does triple its
normal damage, is more accurate, and cleaves with +1 reach. But this
requires 6 attacks performed in a row, without any other actions inbetween
or the count will be reset. This makes its average sustained damage higher
than most brands (especially if the extra reach matters), but also less
flexible. Very natural synergy with WJC, of course!

Since monsters that have anything else they could do besides attack will
never realistically attack 6 times in a row, it works slightly differently
on them: it takes only 4 attacks (though hits a little less hard), but the
only thing they are forbidden from doing is *moving*. This allows the
player some counterplay to keep a monster from sundering them, by refusing
to stand in place and let them. (Monsters also get an icon over their head
to indicate their sunder is charged).

(Sundering icon and vfx made by regret-index, using a CC0 weapon icon made
by Shade and a CC0 slash effect by Cethiel.)

Give oni incarcerators a compensatory nerf for the last two commits

Since their headbutt can now actually happen on turns they drag you, and
also via manifold assault, I've nudged down their base damage and also
their manifold assault cast rate. They already seem quite scary enough
already.

Don't end a monster's attack round as soon as their target moves

This resulted in successful trample/drag attacks by monsters aborting the
rest of their attacks (which in turn had resulted in several monsters
needing trample/drag to be at the end of their attack list, even if it was
their 'primary' attack, damage or theme-wise).

This is no longer the case, and a couple monsters also have their attacks
reordered for fairly arbitrary aesthetic reasons.

(This does mean that thrashing horrors can now push their target two tiles
in the same attack round, but that mostly seems fine to me.)

Refactor handling of monster attack rounds

While melee_attack::launch_attack_set() handled players making multiple
attacks in one round (eg: coglins), it did not do this for monsters.
Instead, fight_melee() would construct one melee_attack per attack that a
monster has and call attack() on each one. But this meant both that any
attempt to make a monster attack *outside* of fight_melee() would only ever
use their first attack, and that it was impossible to apply special attack
properties to a monster's full attack round.

As practical consequences of this, Vhi's Electrolunge, any attacks a
monster made while Vexed, and Manifold Assault could only ever use the
first attack a monster had - just one weapon or one hydra head, etc.
By handling the full attack set inside melee_attack instead, these (and
future special attacks) can all work more properly.

There is one nit in that Manifold Assault still ends up being slightly
asymmetric with the player spell (just in a different way). Player auxes
never happen on projected attacks, but monsters don't define 'aux' as
distinct from any other attack. We can't rely just on it being a weapon
attack, since the 'primary' attack type for many monsters is something else
(eg: Bite or Claw). In interest of simplicity, I am accepting that monsters
with Manifold Assault can simply use all of their attacks.

Add actor::slaying() and monster_info::slaying()

Folding together the player-centric slaying_bonus() function and a bunch of
duplicated code that existed for monsters.

Refactor how many post-attack player effects are handled

There were a variety of effects that could happen after each
'attack action' the player performed (rather than each separate attack()
call, so that things like quick blades and coglins did not cause them to
happen far more rapidly, and projected attacks like Manifold Assault did
not cause them to happen at all). This included Platinum Paragon's followup
attack, Dith shadow mimic melee, as well as duration extensions for effects
like Detonation Catalyst and Werefury that are supposed to be maintained
so long as the player attacks.

However, there were a variety of inconsistencies. Several things that could
logically be considered an 'attack action' did none of these (such as Vhi's
or oni potion cleave). Manifold Assault extended exactly Detonation
Catalyst and no other enchantments. And it was still possible to sometimes
trigger these post-attack effects multiple times in one action anyway (for
instance via Lunge+Rampage (even though Lunge+Whirlwind still only counted
as one)), which could result in net duration gain on detonation catalyst
and similar effects. Coglin Rev also used a probabilistic chance of revving
up for martial attacks, which could result in revving many times in one
turn (or failing to rev at all).

This attempts to standadize behavior a little more, as well as make it
harder to overlook actions which should trigger it:

-Shadow mimic, paragon followup, solar flare, coglin rev, and medusa
 tendrils now can trigger at most once per player turn (no matter how many
 trigger actions might happen on that turn).

-Durations that are intended not to decay so long as the player attacks can
 now be indicated with a D_ATTACK_EXTENDED flag and will automatically not
 decay on any turn an attack was attempted against hostile non-firewood.
 (Where 'attempted' now includes failed attacks due to fumbling in water,
 fear, failing to reach past an ally with a reaching weapon, or failing to
 perform martial attacks due to moving too fast.)

-Vhi's Electric Charge, Bestial Takedown, spellclaws, spellmotor, and oni
 potion cleave can now trigger follow-up attacks. Manifold Assault cannot
 (but will still sustain M_ATTACK_EXTENDED durations). Ripostes do neither.
 The rule is, essentially, that only 'direct' attacks cause post-attack
 effects, and 'bonus' attacks not due to any player action (ie: riposte)
 do not count as an attempted attack by the player (in the same spirit as
 them already not affecting Acrobat status).

-Berserk non-attack penalty tracking and coglin rev are now folded into the
 same function as other post-attack effects, for more centralized handling.

-All of this is normally handled automatically by
 melee_attack::launch_attack_set(), but in cases where a single attack
 action consists of multiple melee_attacks, launch_attack_set(true) should
 be called and then player_attempted_attack() called manually afterward.

This should hopefully make behavior more consistent and also easier to work
with for various future things.

Tweak Elyvilon attack-blocking wrath effect

The way this worked was sort of weird. It could only happen on attacks that
would otherwise had beaten their target's EV, perhaps vaguely attempting to
mimic a shield block, but then it also prevented all auxes from happening
afterward if it did so (unlike a shield block). It could then happen on
auxes specifically, but if it worked there, it prevented only the one aux
attack.

Instead, move it to the top of the function and have Ely prevent the attack
altogether, unconditionally.

Clarify the semantics of multiple attack methods

The attack class had many methods which returned bool, but whose return
value was never checked. In several of these cases, those methods always
returned the same value anyway (though not all of them). I think it was
originally intended to be 'return false if combat should stop at this
point', but even this wasn't respected in practice.

On top of this, the attack() method itself had odd semantics, where it
returned true only if an attack was 'fully completed' and did not abort
early, but this 'abort early' value was interpreted elsewhere as 'attack
did not actually occur', resulting in numerous oddnesses. For instance,
Throatcutter's instakill effect, or landing any killing blow with Wyrmbane
(whether on a dragon or not!) would prevent Dith shadow mimics or platinum
paragons from responding to that attack, since it looked from the outside
the same as a fumble.

Now all methods that returned bool without this being meaningfully used
return void instead. And attack() itself should more consistently return
false only if an attack (as well as any cleaving/multi-hit followups it
might have) all outright fail, due to fumbling, fear, lack of valid
targets, etc. But so long as you actually swing at anything, it should
return true.

(This also fixes a bug where cleaving and multi-hit attacks would report
that they did twice as much damage in total as they actually did. The only
current effect of this is that Enkindled spellclaw attacks with such
weapons would heal twice as much as intended.)

Deduct monster energy in fight_melee instead of inside melee_attack

melee_attack automatically deducted monster energy if the effective attack
number of the attack was 0 (along with some code outside to make sure that
skipped attacks were tallied correctly. This needed compensation in some
other place and also resulted in some bugs on its own (Vexed monsters lost
*two* turns worth of energy for attacking, for instance)

The logic for whether attack::attack() returns true or false has some
unrelated problems that will require changes, so I'm decoupling one of the
two places that actually check this value ahead of time.

Remove a check left over from old Dith player shadows

If a monster can have MID_PLAYER now, there are more important problems
afoot.

New polearms brand: Entangling

This gives a 50% chance to apply low-damage constriction upon weapon hits
(2d2 damage), which has a natural additional synergy with polearms by
possibly blocking a monster's approach to you for several turns. (The
direct damage may seem low, but the significant reduction in enemy EV that
accompanies it should hopefully make it more than equitable to other
brands - and it also helps your aux attacks!)

Only one thing can be constricted by this weapon at a time, and it will end
as soon as you unequip it.

This is also added to unusual_monster_items by default (for characters that
are not immune to constriction).

Remove the Sword of Power

While Valour is not an identical effect, I feel it's occupying a
sufficiently similar space that there's no point in keeping this one
around. I've removed its custom code and effectively turned it into a
vanilla +9 great sword of Valour for those copies that remain in upgraded
saves.

New long blade brand: Valour

Intended as a mild reworking of the Sword of Power effect as a regular
brand, this causes the weapon to fire off short-range penetrating beams of
energy on any melee hit made against an enemy while they are above 80% of
their maximum HP.

The damage is improved by the base damage of the weapon it is on, but is
otherwise unaffected by stats or skill. It is fairly high compared to most
brands as compensation for how easy it is to lose the effect if one doesn't
evade attacks (and the brand also briefly inflicts Weak upon the player
when they remove it, to prevent swapping to a secondary weapon every fight
as they become injured).

The beams will also stop politely before any allies which might be in the
way, making it safe to use in all situations.

(Brand icon made by regret-index, using Ontoclasm's old wand of magic dart
icon and the former Sword of Power tile.)

Relocate the check for allies stopping shots short of hitting the player

To be next to the new stop_at_allies check. (The semantics of this one are
slightly different, which is why I didn't strictly bundle them together.)

This also should remove the need for an additional check that was caused by
rewinding the beam later.

Add bolt.stop_at_allies

This provides a simple way to automatically cut a beam short before it
could reach any ally, simulating aiming at the spot immediately before
them.

This replaces the manual ray tracing that splinterfrost barricade
explosions used to accomplish a similar thing already.

Fix non-spell beams never bouncing off walls

There aren't many beams without an origin_spell used anymore, but there are
a couple. And the code meant to obtain the 'original' range of a beam would
find -1 for them, making it almost impossible for them to have enough range
remaining to ever bounce off a wall - even if their element should
otherwise cause them to do so.

Remove the (almost entirely unused) Drain Magic spell

The only thing still capable of casting it were random Pan lords, and a
LoF-requiring and will-resistable Draining Gaze doesn't seem interesting
enough to keep around in such a limited context.

(Draining Gaze itself might even make sense, but I'll leave adjusting their
spellsets until Hellpan work starts in earnest.)

Slightly refactor applying antimagic to actors

It now uses a method on Actor rather than enchant_actor_with_flavour() via
BEAM_DRAIN_MAGIC.

(This is arguably a little tidier, but also gives a bit more flexibility
for future effects using antimagic beams.)
